post.title: Question: what's the best Christian reply to the Epicurus paradox?

body:
God doesn't prevent evil because then there'd be no point in giving us free will. If God wanted to he could theoretically just make evrything perfect and happy but then we'd have no free will, there'd be no point to anything.

It'd be like an artist painting a canvas entirely black or leaving it blank for fear of making a minor error- it defeats the purpose entirely.

There are various reasons why the 'arguments'/assertions of this so-called paradox are fallacious and represent a fundamental misunderstanding of Christianity.

To answer the questions posed by the flow chart:

"Can God prevent evil?": Yes, and he has on multiple occasions.

Next one is yes, not even worth explaining

"Does God wnat to prevent Evil?"- yes and no. He definitely hates sin and evil and degeneracy, but He does not hate those that commit it. Destroying evil is our job, He's given us the tools to do it. To claim God isn't loving just because He doesn't do everything for us is childish, although coming from someone who was not only Greek (the culture that gifted us with pedophilia and homosexuality) but also had quite the taste for booze and whores, is unsurprising. 

"Then why is there Evil?"- Because of Satan and those who follow him. God could, if He really wanted to, almost certainly destroy/damn Satan and all those who follow him. But He already plans to do that, it's clearly outlined as such in the Bible. I don't want to guess as to God's reasoning, but allowing Satan to run around and think he's winning will make his downfall to eternal damnation shortly therefater even more meaningful and triumphant. 

"Could God have created a universe without evil?"- Yes, but that would defeat the point, as previously stated. The statement "God is all powerful" is also somewhat misleading, as God created intricate rules for the universe and existence, and has obviously tried to follow said rules as much as possible. A universe where free will exists and where events occur naturally *requires* evil if it exists. God did not create Satan or his minions, or at least, not in their current, evil state. 

"Could God have created a free-will universe without evil?"- Yes, but He did not. Although the reasoning has been previously stated, I will reiterate in a fashion that answers the question: God did not create evil, evil is a rebellion against God. God created His subsequent creations not long before (or perhaps it was after? I didn't exactly remember the timeline) this fall and creation of evil. When God allowed free will exist, He knew that evil would seep in and corrupt people, but ultimately found it to be worthwhile that humans be capable of independent thought and feeling.

Overall, analyzing God's ideas or merits or what have you is fruitless. because nobody can really hope to understand God or His actions fully and especially not with complete assurance. Trying to do so can lead you to flawed or even dangerous mindsets. Sometimes God is EXTREMELY clear on what His ideas or purpose was, but much of the time such information cannot be known for sure.

And to say God is bad or unloving or other negative things like that is childish and stupid. God created the universe. Too bad if you don't like it, He created it, He controls it, and He has made all the decisions and will continue to do so ad infinitum. He cannot be wrong because it's the place he so intricately and caringly built specifically for us and any other of His creations that may or may not exist out there, past, present, or if He decides to make more, in the future.

Tl;dr: His house, His rules, His decisions.

post.title: Question: what's the best Christian reply to the Epicurus paradox?

author.bio: I draw, and sometimes I even comment.
author.bio_html: I draw, and sometimes I even comment.

body:
Can God create a rock so heavy that he cannot lift it? Let's break it down breakdance.jpeg
Can a being who can lift all things carry an unliftable rock? Can a being who can create all things create a rock so heavy that the being who can lift all things cannot lift?
The answer is obviously no. Not because the being is not omnipotent. But because it is illogical. It is a contradiction.
In the same way, God could not create a world that contains both free will and no potential to do evil, because the potential to do ill is inherent in free will. Not because he is not all-powerful, but because it is a paradox.

Not because he is not all-powerful, but because it is a paradox.

post.title: Question: what's the best Christian reply to the Epicurus paradox?

body:
Let's pretend evil is required to have free will: You made men capable of evil, then punish them for being evil by sentencing them to a (virtually) eternal pyre. Why? There can be but one reason: You(Their Creator) is malignant.

Evil only makes sense in the world we live in if there is no God, God is apathetic, or if God is also evil. All three incompatible with Monotheistic faith. There are no non-paradoxical alternatives.

You've answered this paradox, but only because the paradox fails to account for something (conveniently) extremely obvious.

"His house, his rules." is tyrannical.

The statement "God is all powerful" is also somewhat misleading, as God created intricate rules for the universe and existence, and has obviously tried to follow said rules as much as possible. A universe where free will exists and where events occur naturally requires evil if it exists. God did not create Satan or his minions, or at least, not in their current, evil state.

"Could God have created a free-will universe without evil?"- Yes, but He did not. Although the reasoning has been previously stated, I will reiterate in a fashion that answers the question: God did not create evil, evil is a rebellion against God. God created His subsequent creations not long before (or perhaps it was after? I didn't exactly remember the timeline) this fall and creation of evil. When God allowed free will exist, He knew that evil would seep in and corrupt people, but ultimately found it to be worthwhile that humans be capable of independent thought and feeling.

Overall, analyzing God's ideas or merits or what have you is fruitless. because nobody can really hope to understand God or His actions fully and especially not with complete assurance. Trying to do so can lead you to flawed or even dangerous mindsets. Sometimes God is EXTREMELY clear on what His ideas or purpose was, but much of the time such information cannot be known for sure.

And to say God is bad or unloving or other negative things like that is childish and stupid. God created the universe. Too bad if you don't like it, He created it, He controls it, and He has made all the decisions and will continue to do so ad infinitum. He cannot be wrong because it's the place he so intricately and caringly built specifically for us and any other of His creations that may or may not exist out there, past, present, or if He decides to make more, in the future.

Tl;dr: His house, His rules, His decisions.

parent.body:
Let's pretend evil is required to have free will: You made men capable of evil, then punish them for being evil by sentencing them to a (virtually) eternal pyre. Why? There can be but one reason: You(Their Creator) is malignant.

Evil only makes sense in the world we live in if there is no God, God is apathetic, or if God is also evil. All three incompatible with Monotheistic faith. There are no non-paradoxical alternatives.

You've answered this paradox, but only because the paradox fails to account for something (conveniently) extremely obvious.

"His house, his rules." is tyrannical.

body: It's not speculation. All the references to "hell" in the new testament are actually *hades* or *Gehenna*, the former being a translation of *sheol*, hebrew for grave or pit, and the latter is a valley where the jews burned garbage 24/7, including the bodies of people they thought didn't deserve a burial. The only possible reference to an a hell is in the parable of the rich man and Lazarus, which could very well be allegorical or even an interpolation (yes, this happened, and a lot). There are no other references outside of Revelation, which is even more difficult to take literally. Other than that no one seems to have known about anything but death, including the earliest saints who interpreted "eternal fire" as a metaphor for destruction.

The only possible reference to an a hell is in the parable of the rich man and Lazarus, which could very well be allegorical or even an interpolation (yes, this happened, and a lot). There are no other references outside of Revelation, which is even more difficult to take literally. Other than that no one seems to have known about anything but death, including the earliest saints who interpreted "eternal fire" as a metaphor for destruction.

post.title: Question: what's the best Christian reply to the Epicurus paradox?

body: Something that is unchanging and fundamental cannot be tyrannical. Constructions that go against them are. God and nature are good (the former perfectly so, the latter needing a little bit of human ingenuity and help to be better), capitalism, communism, liberalism, etc are bad because they directly defy both God *and* nature and try to create irreligious and supranatural system.

body: Do you even know the first thing about God? Tell me, if nature is so good in its current state then why does it need to be completely destroyed and rebuilt from scratch? How is nature unchanging and fundamental? You have made "nature" into an idol and placed it above God. And you say it needs *human* tampering to make it better? More of that is the last thing we need! When have humans ever done anything more than create self-serving power structures for the elites in charge? Indeed, is that not what you're already complaining about when you say "Constructions that go against them are"?

post.title: Question: what's the best Christian reply to the Epicurus paradox?

body:
> Tell me, if nature is so good in its current state then why does it need to be completely destroyed and rebuilt from scratch?

It doesn't. When did I ever say that?

> You have made "nature" into an idol and placed it above God

How so?

> And you say it needs human tampering to make it better? More of that is the last thing we need!

No, it needs human "tampering" to protect it and to allow humans a more secure life.

> When have humans ever done anything more than create self-serving power structures for the elites in charge

Plenty of times.

> Indeed, is that not what you're already complaining about when you say "Constructions that go against them are"?

yes, it is, but you seem to be the anarchist type that views any civilization or government as going against nature/God, when that definitely isn't the case.

body:
> It doesn't. When did I ever say that?

It evidently does, because the heavens and earth will pass away, and the spirit and flesh are opposed.

> How so?

Because it's the result of the fall and a broken reality, and you insist that it should dictate God's actions.

> No, it needs human "tampering" to protect it and to allow humans a more secure life.

So when someone complains about it in a way *you* don't like you say those are just the rules, too bad, sucks to be you loser, but when you think it needs changed in a different way that's all of a sudden completely fine.

> Plenty of times.

Yeah, they're good at pretending to, but it's nearly always a selfish motive disguised as charity. That's how power structures work, and our tribalistic and hierarchical minds are gullible to it.

> yes, it is, but you seem to be the anarchist type that views any civilization or government as going against nature/God, when that definitely isn't the case.

You dodged my calling out of your hypocrisy about calling constructions about nature bad but supporting certain human tampering yourself. But while we're on this subject, civilizations and governments, as you see them, *are* bad and going against God. They're not necessarily against nature, as extreme hierarchy and divisions with elite ruling classes are the primal default. But they are bad, and although allowed by God for a reason are still by Satan (Matthew 4, 1 Samuel 8).

But they are bad, and although allowed by God for a reason are still by Satan (Matthew 4, 1 Samuel 8).
